And how does it make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it,\" he said at the time.\n\nNow that Harris is the de facto Democratic candidate for president, the interview has resurfaced, and Aniston has a few thoughts on Vance's comments.\n\nThe actor took to Instagram on July 25 to share her opinion on the matter. In her Instagram story, she posted an X post about the interview and added the following caption.\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of the United States,\" she wrote.\n\nAniston, who has been open about her own fertility struggles, also addressed the Republican party's efforts to block access to in vitro fertilization (IVF).\n\n\"All I can say is... Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too,\" Aniston continued.\n\nAniston has previously shared thoughts about trying to have children, and \"the pressure\" she faced.\n\n\"I don't like (the pressure) that people put on me, on women -- that you've failed yourself as a female because you haven't procreated,\" she told Allure in 2015. \"I don't think it's fair. You may not have a child come out of your vagina, but that doesn't mean you aren't mothering -- dogs, friends, friends' children.\"\n\nShe opened up to the same publication in 2022 about trying to have a child.\n\n\"It was a challenging road for me, the baby-making road,\" she said, ultimately concluding, \"The ship has sailed.\"\n\n\"I have zero regrets,\" she continued. \"I actually feel a little relief now because there is no more, 'Can I? Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\"\n\nVance is a father of three, including two-year-old daughter Mirabel.\n\nHarris' stepdaughter Ella Emhoff also spoke out against Vance, writing on Instagram: \"How can you be 'childless' when you have cutie-pie kids like Cole and I? I love my three parents.\"\n\nDoug Emhoff's ex-wife Kerstin Emhoff told NBC News: \"For over 10 years, since Cole and Ella were teenagers, Kamala has been a co-parent with Doug and I.\n\n\"She is loving, nurturing, fiercely protective, and always present. I love our blended family and am grateful to have her in it.\"\n\nBiden has endorsed Harris as his heir apparent ahead of the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next month.\n\nBiden formally dropped out of the race on Sunday US time.\n\nAniston's rare call out comes years after revealing the IVF treatments she underwent while married to actor Brad Pitt from 2000 to 2005.\n\n\"All the years and years and years of speculation (over when the couple would have children) ... it was really hard. I was going through IVF, drinking Chinese teas -- you name it. I was throwing everything at it,\" Aniston told Allure.\n\n\"I would have given anything if someone had said to me, 'Freeze your eggs. Do yourself a favour.' You just don't think it. So here I am today. The ship has sailed.\"\n\nHowever, the actress said she has had \"zero regrets\".\n\n\"I actually feel a little relief now because there is no more, 'Can I? Maybe. Maybe. Maybe.' I don't have to think about that anymore.\"\n\nAniston was married to fellow actor Pitt from 2000 to 2005, and to then actor Justin Theroux between 2015 and 2017.\n\nAniston has previously talked Vance's weird \"childless cat ladies\" comment", "body": "\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States\"\n\nJennifer Aniston has slammed J.D. Vance after comments of the vice presidential candidate mocking \"childless cat ladies\" recently resurfaced on the internet.\n\nDuring a 2021 appearance on Tucker Carlson's now-canceled Fox News show, Vance said the country was being run by Democratic \"corporate oligarchs\" who had been chosen by a \"bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made, and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable too.\"\n\nVance continued: \"You look at [Vice President] Kamala Harris, [Transportation Secretary] Pete Buttigieg, [Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.)]: The entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without children, and how does it make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it?\" (Editor's Note: Harris is the stepmother of two children through her marriage to second gentleman Douglas Emhoff, while Buttigieg and his husband, Chasten, announced the birth of twins in September 2021.)\n\nAniston reposted Vance's comments to her Instagram on Wednesday night, writing as a caption: \"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States.\"\n\nThe Friends and Morning Show star then added: \"I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to [in vitro fertilization] as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\"\n\nAnniston has been open in the past about her struggles with getting pregnant, revealing that she underwent unsuccessful rounds of in vitro fertilization. JD Vance (R-Ohio) for past comments on women who don't have children .\n\nThe \"Friends\" star took aim at Donald Trump's new running mate for griping to Tucker Carlson in 2021 that the country was run by a \"bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable, too.\"\n\nVance mentioned Vice President Kamala Harris, who is a stepmother to two children with her husband Doug Emhoff, as one of them. Harris has quickly emerged as the presumptive Democratic nominee after President Joe Biden withdrew from the race.\n\nAniston took to her Instagram stories to blast the attitude of Vance, an opponent of the Right to IVF Act, toward reproductive rights and choice.\n\n\"I can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States,\" wrote the \"Morning Show\" actor, who rarely makes public comments on politics. \"All I can say is ... Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\"\n\nVance has a 2-year-old daughter and two sons, aged 4 and 6.\n\nAniston has shared her IVF and fertility struggles, criticizing tabloid speculation over whether she was pregnant in a 2016 HuffPost essay.\n\n\"We are complete with or without a mate, with or without a child,\" she wrote. \"We get to decide for ourselves what is {"uri": "8243649176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:19:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:19:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:18:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/jd-vance-slammed-childless-cat-ladies-comment/story?id=112272258", "title": "JD Vance slammed for 'childless cat ladies' comment", "body": "Vance smeared Kamala Harris as a \"childless cat lady\" on Fox News in 2021.\n\nA Fox News interview from 2021, in which Sen. JD Vance smeared Vice President Kamala Harris as a \"childless cat lady,\" has resurfaced since he became the Republican vice presidential nominee, sparking widespread anger.\n\nIn the clip, Vance questioned Democrats -- including Harris, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg and U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez -- for not having biological children.\n\n\"We are effectively run in this country via the Democrats, via our corporate oligarchs, by a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable too,\" Vance said.\n\n\"How does it make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it?\" he asked.\n\nThe 2021 interview began circulating widely after Hillary Clinton shared the clip on X. \"What a normal, relatable guy who certainly doesn't hate women having freedoms,\" she wrote.\n\nVance did not immediately respond to a request for comment from ABC News.\n\nThough Harris does not have biological children, she does have two stepchildren -- Cole and Ella Emhoff -- who have lovingly referred to her as \"Momala.\"\n\nKerstin Emhoff -- second gentleman Doug Emhoff's ex-wife, and mother to Cole and Ella Emhoff -- has been a vocal supporter of Harris, and defended her against attacks about her parental status.\n\n\"These are baseless attacks. For over 10 years, since Cole and Ella were teenagers, Kamala has been a co-parent with Doug and I,\" she said. \"She is loving, nurturing, fiercely protective, and always present. I love our blended family and am grateful to have her in it.\"\n\nElla Emhoff shared her mother's statement on Instagram, writing, \"I love my three parents.\"\n\n\"How can you be 'childless' when you have cutie pie kids like Cole and I?\" she added.\n\nButtigieg also hit back against Vance's comments, saying in a CNN interview that Vance should not speak about other people's children.\n\n\"The really sad thing is he said that after Chasten and I had been through a fairly heartbreaking setback in our adoption journey,\" Buttigieg said. \"He couldn't have known that, but maybe that's why you shouldn't be talking about other people's children, and it's not about his kids or my kids or the vice president's family. It's about your family, people's families whose well-being will depend on whether we go into a future led by somebody like Kamala Harris, who is focused on expanding the prosperity, the freedom, the well-being of our families.\n\nActress Jennifer Aniston, who has spoken about her struggles with fertility, made a post on Instagram slamming Vance, who has voted against establishing federal protections for in vitro fertilization.\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States,\" Aniston wrote. \"All I can say is ... Mr Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her too.\"\n\nVance's comments have even struck a nerve with some prominent conservative women.\n\n\"One of my best friends did rounds and rounds of unsuccessful IVF wanting to have a child. It is still painful to talk about,\" Meghan McCain said in an X post. \"This 'childless women' comment by JD Vance has made so many waves with so many different friends of mine for its insensitivity and cruelty to women.\"\n\nBeverly Hallberg, a fellow with the conservative nonprofit Independent Women's Forum, replied to McCain's post.\n\n\"I'm childless on earth, but I have a baby in heaven due to an ectopic pregnancy,\" Hallberg said. \"Not all women who don't have children are childless by choice. It adds insult to injury, to put it mildly, when these comments are said.\"\n\nCorie Whalen, media relations director at a Republican think tank and former congressional staffer, said on X she was disgusted by Vance's comments.\n\n\"I'm a right-leaning woman who agrees with almost nothing the Biden-Harris administration has done, but the primal hatred and disgust Vance stokes in me transcends politics,\" she wrote. \"I suspect I am not the only woman of my vintage, so to speak, who feels this way.\"\n\nThe head of a major infertility nonprofit also spoke out against Vance, calling his comments \"painful and tone-deaf.\"\n\n\"People are childfree for many reasons -- from grieving the pain of miscarriage to experiencing failed adoptions or rounds of fertility treatments to making their own choice not to have children,\" said Barbara Collura, president and CEO of RESOLVE: The National Infertility Association.\n\n\"For some, living without children doesn't feel like a choice that they made, but a choice that they live with, despite trying to grow their families,\" Collura added. \"Under no circumstances, should living childfree be weaponized in a way that degrades people or their value to society.\"\n\nIn an interview with ABC News at the American Teachers Federation Conference in Houston, Briget Rein -- a former Brooklyn teacher, who wore a pink shirt that said \"Cats Against Trump\" -- proudly identified herself as a \"cat lady\" and said she thought Vance's remarks were \"stupid.\"\n\n\"Vance also is unprepared to be a vice president, he's not prepared. Because he's busy looking at the surface. He's not looking at the full picture,\" she said.\"You know, this cat lady went to college. This cat lady went to work ... but he's busy talking about cat ladies, and talking about women in a very derogatory fashion.\"", "source": {"uri": "abcnews.go.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC Taking to her Instagram stories on Wednesday (July 24), the actress reposted a clip of Vance's interview from 2021 when he running for the post of Ohio Senator. In the clip, Vance could be heard saying that the US is being run by \" a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made, and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable.\" Aniston, who has been open about her own struggles with infertility, expressed her outrage and wrote, \"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of {"uri": "8243452152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:14:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:14:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:13:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/07/25/childless-cat-ladies-jennifer-aniston-and-swifties-take-on-jd-vance/", "title": "'Childless cat ladies,' Jennifer Aniston, and Swifties take on JD Vance", "body": "Republican vice presidential candidate Sen. JD Vance, R-Ohio, speaks at a campaign rally at Radford University on Monday in Radford, Va. Julia Nikhinson/Associated Press\n\nThree years ago, well before JD Vance was selected as Donald Trump's running mate, he suggested in a TV interview that some Democrats including Vice President Harris are \"a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable.\"\n\nThose 2021 comments are resurfacing on social media now that Harris is the likely Democratic nominee, sparking a fresh wave of anger from women who say it's offensive to those struggling with fertility issues - and inaccurate that people without children \"don't really have a direct stake\" in the country's future.\n\nAt the same time, many on social media are embracing and owning the \"childless cat lady\" label as a point of pride, with many even pointing to reported billionaire Taylor Swift as a prime example of a highly successful one - seen even on her 2023 Time \"Person of the Year\" cover with her fluffy rag doll wrapped around her neck.\n\n\"There's a movement,\" declared Nikki Barnes, a previous member of the Democratic National Committee from Florida, accompanied by a \"Childless cat ladies for Harris 2024\" image quickly amassing nearly 2 million views. On TikTok, people are snapping up \"Cat ladies for Harris 2024\" stickers.\n\nThe vociferous response to the resurfaced Vance comments - which have been shared widely and amassed nearly 28 million views on an X post shared Monday - only underscores how female reproductive rights including access to abortion, birth control and in vitro fertilization will be major drivers in the 2024 race. Gender and racial attacks like the ones she experienced as a primary candidate in the 2020 race are poised to accelerate now that she's the likely nominee.\n\nFor the record, Harris, 59, became a stepmom of two when she married Douglas Emhoff in 2014 and has been deeply involved in the lives of stepchildren Ella and Cole. And Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, whom Vance also named in his comments describing how \"the entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without children,\" became a parent of adopted twins.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHarris spokesman Ammar Moussa said that \"unlike Donald Trump and JD Vance, Vice President Harris understands that every single American has a stake in this country's future.\"\n\nBIOLOGICAL CHILDREN AREN'T ALWAYS AN OPTION\n\nVance's campaign is pointing to a different speech from July 2021 in which he targeted the \"childless left\" but added a caveat: that \"there are people, of course, for biological reasons, medical reasons that can't have children. The target of these remarks is not them.\"\n\nYet many women remind Vance that there are plenty of reasons why they may not have children.\n\nJennifer Aniston arrives at a screening of \"The Morning Show\" during PaleyFest on April 12, at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles. Richard Shotwell/Invision via Associated Press file\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States,\" actress Jennifer Aniston wrote Wednesday, slamming Vance in an Instagram story. \"Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day,\" wrote the \"Friends\" star.\n\n\"I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\" (While Trump has declared support for in vitro fertilization, Senate Republicans last month blocked consideration of a bill to protect IVF access - and the issue erupted in February when the Alabama Supreme Court ruled that frozen embryos are people and that a person could be liable for destroying them.)\n\nAdvertisement\n\nReproductive health issues, especially conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and endometriosis can impact women's ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy. Female fertility declines with age and lack of adequate health-care services or child support services can also be factors influencing the decision to have a child.\n\nAniston has previously been candid about the challenges of trying to get pregnant - and has previously written about how \"we don't need to be married or mothers to be complete.\"\n\n'The View\" host Whoopi Goldberg also weighed in on the show Wednesday: \"Sir, there are people who have chosen not to have children for whatever reason,\" she said. \"There are people who want to have children who cannot. How dare you. You never had a baby; your wife had a baby ... you know nothing about this.\"\n\nMeghan McCain, talk show host and daughter of the late GOP senator John McCain of Arizona, posted on X that \"I have been trying to warn every conservative man I know - these JD comments are activating women across all sides, including my most conservative Trump-supporting friends.\" The remarks \"have caused real pain and are just innately unchristian. This is not who we are,\" she said.\n\nButtigieg in a CNN interview, said Vance's remarks came on the heels of their difficult journey to adoption. \"He couldn't have known that, but maybe that's why you shouldn't be talking about other people's children,\" Buttigieg said.\n\n'CHILDLESS CAT LADIES' EMBRACING SOCIAL MEDIA LABEL\n\nAdvertisement\n\nVance, in his 2021 comments, called out \"childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices they've made and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable too.\" Women online blasted the assumption that those who are without children are unhappy.\n\n\"I had absolutely no idea I was miserable,\" actor Liz Vassey, known for her role on \"CSI,\" wrote on X. \"Thank God there was a man around to tell me.\"\n\nVance's comments came as more Americans are choosing not to have children. A Pew Research Survey in 2021 found that the number of childless U.S. adults aged 18 to 49 who said they were unlikely to ever have children rose by 7 percentage points in the previous three years to 44%. About 56% said they did not want children, 19% stated a medical reason for not having kids, and financial reasons stopped another 17% from becoming a parent.\n\nAs some on social media put it: Childless cat ladies vote, too - and some, even, are cultural icons. \"It's bold, for someone seeking votes, to hone in on 'childless cat ladies' when the leader of Childless Cat Ladies is TAYLOR SWIFT,\" author Caitlin Moran posted. Swift, 34, has three cats and has described them as some of her biggest influences.\n\nSure enough, Swifties were entering the chat in droves. One TikToker added Swift's Time cover to the soundtrack of \"Who's Afraid of Little Old Me?\"\n\nAnother posted a video of Swift riding a giant rendering of her cat Olivia dressed as a unicorn, with the text: \"Childless cat ladies riding to polls in November to vote for Harris.\"\n\nLegal fellow and Lawfare correspondent Anna Bower pointed out on X: \"hell hath no fury like a certain childless cat lady who has yet to endorse a presidential candidate.\"\n\nCopy the Story Link Related Headlines JD Vance leads Trump's push to win key 'blue wall' states\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\n\" Previous\n\nMainers are filling in as extras in the opera 'Aida.' {"uri": "8243694086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:07:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:07:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:06:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/jd-vance-slammed-childless-cat-201407031.html", "title": "JD Vance slammed for 'childless cat ladies' comment", "body": "A Fox News interview from 2021, in which Sen. JD Vance smeared Vice President Kamala Harris as one of a group of \"childless cat ladies,\" has resurfaced since he became the Republican vice presidential nominee, sparking widespread anger.\n\nIn the clip, Vance questioned Democrats -- including Harris, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg and U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez -- for not having biological children.\n\n\"We are effectively run in this country via the Democrats, via our corporate oligarchs, by a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable too,\" Vance said.\n\nMORE: Kamala Harris is a stepmom of 2: What to know about her family\n\n\"How does it make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it?\" he asked.\n\nThe 2021 interview began circulating widely after Hillary Clinton shared the clip on X. \"What a normal, relatable guy who certainly doesn't hate women having freedoms,\" she wrote.\n\nVance did not immediately respond to a request for comment from ABC News.\n\nThough Harris does not have biological children, she does have two stepchildren -- Cole and Ella Emhoff -- who have lovingly referred to her as \"Momala.\"\n\nKerstin Emhoff -- second gentleman Doug Emhoff's ex-wife, and mother to Cole and Ella Emhoff -- has been a vocal supporter of Harris, and defended her against attacks about her parental status.\n\n\"These are baseless attacks. For over 10 years, since Cole and Ella were teenagers, Kamala has been a co-parent with Doug and I,\" she said. \"She is loving, nurturing, fiercely protective, and always present. I love our blended family and am grateful to have her in it.\"\n\nElla Emhoff shared her mother's statement on Instagram, writing, \"I love my three parents.\"\n\nMORE: Vance years ago expressed support for Iraq War, despite current criticism\n\n\"How can you be 'childless' when you have cutie pie kids like Cole and I?\" she added.\n\nButtigieg also hit back against Vance's comments, saying in a CNN interview that Vance should not speak about other people's children.\n\n\"The really sad thing is he said that after Chasten and I had been through a fairly heartbreaking setback in our adoption journey,\" Buttigieg said. \"He couldn't have known that, but maybe that's why you shouldn't be talking about other people's children, and it's not about his kids or my kids or the vice president's family. It's about your family, people's families whose well-being will depend on whether we go into a future led by somebody like Kamala Harris, who is focused on expanding the prosperity, the freedom, the well-being of our families.\n\nActress Jennifer Aniston, who has spoken about her struggles with fertility, made a post on Instagram slamming Vance, who has voted against establishing federal protections for in vitro fertilization.\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States,\" Aniston wrote. \"All I can say is ... Mr Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her too.\"\n\nVance's comments have even struck a nerve with some prominent conservative women.\n\n\"One of my best friends did rounds and rounds of unsuccessful IVF wanting to have a child. It is still painful to talk about,\" Meghan McCain said in an X post. \"This 'childless women' comment by JD Vance has made so many waves with so many different friends of mine for its insensitivity and cruelty to women.\"\n\nBeverly Hallberg, a fellow with the conservative nonprofit Independent Women's Forum, replied to McCain's post.\n\n\"I'm childless on earth, but I have a baby in heaven due to an ectopic pregnancy,\" Hallberg said. \"Not all women who don't have children are childless by choice. It adds insult to injury, to put it mildly, when these comments are said.\"\n\nMORE: 'Kamala IS brat': How Kamala Harris' campaign is embracing the memes\n\nCorie Whalen, media relations director at a Republican think tank and former congressional staffer, said on X she was disgusted by Vance's comments.\n\n\"I'm a right-leaning woman who agrees with almost nothing the Biden-Harris administration has done, but the primal hatred and disgust Vance stokes in me transcends politics,\" she wrote. \"I suspect I am not the only woman of my vintage, so to speak, who feels this way.\"\n\nThe head of a major infertility nonprofit also spoke out against Vance, calling his comments \"painful and tone-deaf.\"\n\n\"People are childfree for many reasons -- from grieving the pain of miscarriage to experiencing failed adoptions or rounds of fertility treatments to making their own choice not to have children,\" said Barbara Collura, president and CEO of RESOLVE: The National Infertility Association.\n\n\"For some, living without children doesn't feel like a choice that they made, but a choice that they live with, despite trying to grow their families,\" Collura added. \"Under no circumstances, should living childfree be weaponized in a way that degrades people or their value to society.\"\n\nIn an interview with ABC News at the American Teachers Federation Conference in Houston, Briget Rein -- a former Brooklyn teacher, who wore a pink shirt that said \"Cats Against Trump\" -- proudly identified herself as a \"cat lady\" and said she thought Vance's remarks were \"stupid.\"\n\n\"Vance also is unprepared to be a vice president, he's not prepared. Because he's busy looking at the surface. He's not looking at the full picture,\" she said.\"You know, this cat lady went to college. This cat lady went to work ... but he's busy talking about cat ladies, and talking about women in a very derogatory fashion.\"\n\nSen. Kirsten Gillibrand, D-N.Y., argued that even small attacks on Harris -- even if Harris and her campaign embrace the incoming and try to make light of it -- could undermine her, pointing to the 2021 video of the comments from Vance.\n\n\"It's really undermining her, and the fact that we get fixated on it and repeat it, and even though we just do memes and try to make it funny, we're literally talking about that she's a cat owner,\" Gillibrand said Wednesday night after a screening of a documentary on Geraldine Ferraro. \"It's absurd. {"uri": "8243094303", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:00:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:00:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:59:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.westmeathindependent.ie/2024/07/25/jennifer-aniston-hits-out-at-jd-vance-for-calling-childless-women-cat-ladies/", "title": "Jennifer Aniston hits out at JD Vance for calling childless women 'cat ladies' | Westmeath Independent", "body": "Jennifer Aniston hits out at JD Vance for calling childless women 'cat ladies' RSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 25 Jul 2024, 1:27 PM Last updated: Thu 25 Jul 2024, 1:56 PM\n\nBy Casey Cooper-Fiske, PA Entertainment Reporter\n\nFriends star Jennifer Aniston has condemned Donald Trump's running mate JD Vance for calling childless women \"miserable\" and \"cat ladies\".\n\nThe 55-year-old actress posted a story on Instagram with a video of Vance speaking to Tucker Carson on Fox News.\n\nIn the video Vance says: \"We've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it.\n\n\"We're effectively run in this country, via the Democrats and via our corporate oligarchs, by a bunch of childless cat ladies, who are miserable about their own lives and the choices that they've made.\n\n\"So they want to make the rest of the country miserable too.\"\n\nAniston accompanied the video with a caption which said she \"truly can't believe\" the comments came from a potential vice president of the US.\n\nAt the bottom of the post she criticised Vance's anti-IVF stance, and said she hoped his daughter \"will not need to turn to IVF\".\n\nHer post read: \"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of the United States.\n\n\"All I can say is, Mr Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day.\n\n\"I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her too.\"\n\nAniston followed the post with a video of Vice President Kamala Harris asking US Supreme Court associate justice Brett Kavanaugh if he could \"think of any laws that give the government the power to make decisions about the male body?\".\n\nAniston, who was previously married to actor Brad Pitt, does not have any children. She revealed to Allure magazine in 2022 that she had undergone IVF to try to have children when she was in her 30s and 40s, but the attempts did not result in any pregnancies.\n\nThe actress, who is still best known for her role as Rachel Green in Friends, is currently starring in The Morning Show on Apple TV+.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 25 Jul 2024, 1:27 PM Last updated: Thu 25 Jul {"uri": "8242585254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "07:41:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T07:41:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T07:40:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/jennifer-aniston-jd-vance-kamala-harris-friends-b2585589.html", "title": "Jennifer Aniston criticises JD Vance's 'childless cat ladies' comments", "body": "On Wednesday (25 July), the Friends star shared a clip of Vance making the comments on her Instagram story, writing: \"'I truly can't believe that this is coming from a potential VP of the United States.\"\n\nAniston took the opportunity to address Vance directly and criticise his stance on IVF.\n\n\"All I can say is... Mr Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option,\" she wrote. \"Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\"\n\nVance made the comments during a 2021 interview with former Fox News host Tucker Carlson, when he questioned Vice President Kamala Harris' leadership because she does not have biological children.\n\nVance said in the clip that the country was run by \"a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable too\".\n\n\"Look at Kamala Harris, Pete Buttigieg, AOC, the entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without children,\" Vance said. \"How does it make any sense we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it?\"\n\nThe video has gone viral again in the build-up to the presidential election in November, with many women without children branding Vance's comments as sexist, misogynistic and fulfilling a historical stereotype that women who choose not to have children are lonely and unloved.\n\nAmerican actor Liz Vassey, known for her roles on All My Children and on CSI: Crime Scene Investigation, sarcastically replied to Vance's comments on social media: \"I had absolutely no idea I was miserable. Thank God there was a man around to tell me.\"\n\nAnother X/Twitter user wrote: \"As a non-birth giver, I've heard judgments about this since my 20s, but this thing about having no stake in society unless you produce young is very sinister to me.\"\n\n\"I choose not to have kids and I've never regretted it. I'm not lacking anything and my life is quite full, thank you very much,\" a third woman wrote.\n\nOther women on social media pointed out that the comments were insensitive towards women who cannot conceive due to health reasons.\n\nDemocratic presidential candidate Harris, one of the politicians Vance dubbed a \"childless cat lady\", spoke about Vance's stances on IVF and abortion in a campaign speech last week in Kalamazoo, Michigan.\n\n\"Understand, this is a fellow who -- in the United States Senate -- participated in blocking protections for IVF. This is an individual who has made every indication that he is for a national abortion ban,\" said Harris.\n\nIn June, Vance voted to block the Right to IVF Act, which would have protected the accessibility of IVF services nationwide.\n\nAniston, who does not have any children, has been open about her own experience with IVF in the past.\n\nThe We're The Millers actor has long been critical of the stereotype that women who choose not to have children, or cannot have them, have failed in some way.\n\nIn an essay written for Huffington Post in 2016, Aniston wrote that women don't need to be \"married or mothers to be complete\".\n\n\"We get to decide for ourselves what is beautiful when it comes to our bodies. That decision is ours and ours alone,\" she wrote in the essay. \"Let's make that decision for ourselves and for the young women in this world who look to us as examples.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8242448480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "06:03:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T06:03:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T06:03:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.rollingstone.com/tv-movies/tv-movie-news/jennifer-aniston-slams-jd-vance-kamala-harris-comment-1235067605/", "title": "Jennifer Aniston Slams J.D. Vance's 'Childless Cat Ladies' Comment About Women Without Children", "body": "Jennifer Aniston did not mince words as she criticized J.D. Vance's resurfaced 2021 comment that politicians like Vice President Kamala Harris are \"childless cat ladies.\"\n\nOn her Instagram Story Wednesday, the actress reposted a video clip of Vance's interview with then-Fox News host Tucker Carlson as he was running for Ohio senator in 2021. In her post, the actress pointed to Vance's track record of blocking access to fertility treatments.\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States,\" Aniston wrote in reference to Donald Trump's 2024 running mate. \"All I can say is... Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day.\"\n\n\"I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option,\" she continued. \"Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\" (Vance voted against the Right to IVF Act, which looked to protect accessibility and affordability of IVF.)\n\nIn the 2021 interview, Vance told Carlson that the country was being run \"by a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made, and so they wanna make the rest of the country miserable, too.\" He further lamented, \"You look at Kamala Harris, Pete Buttigieg, AOC, the entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without children.\"\n\nHarris is not, however, childless. She shares two stepchildren -- son Cole and daughter Ella -- with Second Gentleman Douglas Emhoff, while Secretary Buttigieg shares twins with his husband Chasten.\n\nIn the past, Aniston has been vocal about her use of in-vitro fertilization, and the difficulty of handling pregnancy rumors in the public eye. \"All the years and years and years of speculation ... It was really hard,\" she told Allure in 2022. \"I was going through IVF, drinking Chinese teas, you name it. I was throwing everything at it. I would have given anything if someone had said to me, 'Freeze your eggs. Do yourself a favor.' You just don't think it.\"\n\n\"I have zero regrets,\" she continued. \"I actually feel a little relief now because there is no more, 'Can I? Maybe. Maybe. Maybe.' {"uri": "8243642348", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:12:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:12:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:11:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2024/jul/25/childless-cat-ladies-jennifer-aniston-and-swifties/", "title": "'Childless cat ladies,' Jennifer Aniston, and Swifties take on JD Vance", "body": "Three years ago, well before JD Vance was selected as Donald Trump's running mate, he suggested in a TV interview that some Democrats including Vice President Harris are \"a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable.\"\n\nThose 2021 comments are resurfacing on social media now that Harris is the likely Democratic nominee, sparking a fresh wave of anger from women who say it's offensive to those struggling with fertility issues - and inaccurate that people without children \"don't really have a direct stake\" in the country's future.\n\nAt the same time, many on social media are embracing and owning the \"childless cat lady\" label as a point of pride, with many even pointing to reported billionaire Taylor Swift as a prime example of a highly successful one - seen even on her 2023 Time \"Person of the Year\" cover with her fluffy rag doll wrapped around her neck.\n\n\"There's a movement,\" declared Nikki Barnes, a previous member of the Democratic National Committee from Florida, accompanied by a \"Childless cat ladies for Harris 2024\" image quickly amassing nearly 2 million views. On TikTok, people are snapping up \"Cat ladies for Harris 2024\" stickers.\n\nThe vociferous response to the resurfaced Vance comments - which have been shared widely and amassed nearly 28 million views on an X post shared Monday - only underscores how female reproductive rights including access to abortion, birth control and in vitro fertilization will be a major drivers in the 2024 race. Gender and racial attacks like the ones she experienced as a primary candidate in the 2020 race are poised to accelerate now that she's the likely nominee.\n\nFor the record, Harris, 59, became a stepmom of two when she married Douglas Emhoff in 2014 and has been deeply involved in the lives of stepchildren Ella and Cole. And Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, whom Vance also named in his comments describing how \"the entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without children,\" became a parent of adopted twins.\n\nHarris spokesman Ammar Moussa said that \"unlike Donald Trump and JD Vance, Vice President Harris understands that every single American has a stake in this country's future.\"\n\nVance's campaign is pointing to a different speech from the July 2021 in which he targeted the \"childless left\" but added a caveat: that \"there are people, of course, for biological reasons, medical reasons that can't have children. The target of these remarks is not them.\"\n\nYet many women are reminding Vance that there are plenty of reasons they may not have children.\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States,\" actress Jennifer Aniston wrote Wednesday, slamming Vance in an Instagram story. \"Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day,\" wrote the \"Friends\" star.\n\n\"I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\" (While Trump has declared support for in vitro fertilization, Senate Republicans last month blocked consideration of a bill to protect IVF access - and the issue erupted in February when the Alabama Supreme Court ruled that frozen embryos are people and that a person could be liable for destroying them.)\n\nReproductive health issues, especially conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and endometriosis can impact women's ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy. Female fertility declines with age and lack of adequate health-care services or child support services can also be factors influencing the decision to have a child.\n\nAniston has previously been candid about the challenges of trying to get pregnant - and has previously written about how \"we don't need to be married or mothers to be complete.\"\n\n'The View\" host Whoopi Goldberg also weighed in on the show Wednesday: \"Sir, there are people who have chosen not to have children for whatever reason,\" she said. \"There are people who want to have children who cannot. How dare you. You never had a baby; your wife had a baby ... you know nothing about this.\"\n\nMeghan McCain, talk show host and daughter of the late GOP senator John McCain of Arizona, posted on X that \"I have been trying to warn every conservative man I know - these JD comments are activating women across all sides, including my most conservative Trump supporting friends.\" The remarks \"have caused real pain and are just innately unchristian. This is not who we are,\" she said.\n\nButtigieg in a CNN interview, said Vance's remarks came on the heels of their difficult journey to adoption. \"He couldn't have known that, but maybe that's why you shouldn't be talking about other people's children,\" Buttigieg said.\n\nVance, in his 2021 comments, called out \"childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices they've made and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable too.\" Women online blasted the assumption that those who are without children are unhappy.\n\n\"I had absolutely no idea I was miserable,\" actor Liz Vassey, known for her role on \"CSI,\" wrote on X. \"Thank God there was a man around to tell me.\"\n\nVance's comments came as more Americans are choosing not to have children. A Pew Research Survey in 2021 found that the childless U.S. adults aged 18 to 49 who said they were unlikely to ever have children rose by 7 percentage points in the previous three years to 44 percent. About 56 percent said they did not want children, 19 percent stated a medical reason for not having kids, and financial reasons stopped another 17 percent from becoming a parent.\n\nAs some on social media put it: Childless cat ladies vote, too - and some, even, are cultural icons. \"It's bold, for someone seeking votes, to hone in on 'childless cat ladies' when the leader of Childless Cat Ladies is TAYLOR SWIFT,\" author Caitlin Moran posted. Swift, 34, has three cats and has described them as some of her biggest influences.\n\nSure enough, Swifties were entering the chat in droves. One TikToker added Swift's Time cover to the soundtrack of \"Who's Afraid of Little Old Me?\"\n\nAnother posted a video of Swift riding a giant rendering of her cat Olivia dressed as a unicorn, with the text: \"Childless cat ladies riding to polls in November to vote for Harris.\"\n\nLegal fellow and Lawfare correspondent Anna Bower pointed out on X: \"hell hath no fury like a certain childless cat lady who has yet to endorse a presidential candidate.\"", "source": {"uri": "spokesman.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Spokesman Review"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243372694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:14:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:14:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:12:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/conservative-women-jd-vance-childless-democrats-kamala-harris-1930239", "title": "Conservative women turn on JD Vance for attacking \"childless\" Democrats", "body": "A number of conservative women have criticized Donald Trump's running mate, Senator JD Vance, after his \"childless cat ladies\" comment reemerged.\n\n\"We're effectively run in this country -- via the Democrats, via our corporate oligarchs -- by a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made, and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable, too,\" Vance said, adding, \"You look at Kamala Harris, Pete Buttigieg, AOC, the entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without children. And how does it make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it.\"\n\nSince Vance's comments resurfaced, conservative women have spoken out against them, suggesting the remarks could damaged Trump's 2024 election hopes, given how important the female vote is to the GOP ticket.\n\nCorie Whalen, a onetime communications director for former Michigan Representative Justin Amash, a Republican, posted on X, formerly Twitter: \"I'm a right-leaning woman who agrees with almost nothing the Biden-Harris administration has done, but the primal hatred and disgust Vance stokes in me transcends politics.\n\n\"I suspect I am not the only woman of my vintage, so to speak, who feels this way.\"\n\nBeverly Hallberg, the president of District Media Group and a Fox News contributor, wrote on X: \"I'm childless on earth, but I have a baby in heaven due to an ectopic pregnancy. Not all women who don't have children are childless by choice. It adds insult to injury, to put it mildly, when these comments are said.\"\n\nIn a follow-up post, Hallberg added: \"Even if a politician is talking only about childless women who choose not to have kids (even tho that wasn't stated), it puts women who desire motherhood in the difficult position of having to explain that they aren't a liberal feminist, even though they are childless.\n\n\"It's not helpful to women, including conservative women like myself, and it's an unforced messaging error by a politician.\"\n\nMeghan McCain, a former host of The View and the daughter of late Arizona Senator John McCain, wrote on X: \"One of my best friends did rounds and rounds of unsuccessful IVF wanting to have a child. It is still painful to talk about.\n\n\"This 'childless women' comment by JD Vance has made so many waves with so many different friends of mine for its insensitivity and cruelty to women.\"\n\nNewsweek has contacted Vance's office for comment via email.\n\nElsewhere, actress Jennifer Aniston also condemned Vance over his remarks. The Friends star has previously spoken out about trying to have children through in vitro fertilization.\n\n\"All I can say is ... Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day,\" Aniston wrote on her Instagram stories. \"I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\"\n\nIn June, Vance voted against the Right to IVF Act, which would have protected accessibility and affordability of IVF services across the U.S.\n\nVance has also expressed support for a national abortion ban, including in the case of rape or incest.\n\n\"It's not whether a woman should be forced to bring a child to term. It's whether a child should be allowed to live, even though the circumstances of that child's birth are somehow inconvenient or a problem to the society,\" Vance said in 2021. \"The question really, to me, is about the baby.\"\n\nIn a recent interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity, Vance accused the Democrats of misquoting his views that a pregnancy from rape or incest was \"inconvenient.\"\n\n\"The Democrats have completely twisted my words,\" Vance said. \"What I did say is that we sometimes in this society see babies as inconveniences, and I absolutely want us to Vance's resurfaced comments about \"childless cat ladies\" running America.\n\nFollowing Donald Trump's decision to partner with the Hillbilly Elegy subject as his running mate in the upcoming election, the Friends and Morning Show actress condemned the Ohio author-politician for his stance on limiting reproductive rights in the United States.\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States,\" the 55-year-old star wrote Wednesday on her Instagram Story, in addition to sharing a 2021 clip of Vance's controversial interview with conservative media personality Tucker Carlson.\n\nAniston then turned the conversation back on Vance, reminding him that he and wife Usha Vance have a daughter of their own.\n\n\"All I can say is... Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option,\" Aniston wrote. \"Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\"\n\nIn the three-year-old interview with Carlson, Vance said \"we're effectively run in this country, via the Democrats, via our corporate oligarchs, by a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made,\" estimating that \"they want to make the rest of the country miserable, too.\" He specifically named Vice President Kamala Harris, Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, and Pete Buttigieg -- who's married to husband Chasten Buttigieg -- as examples.\n\nSign up for Entertainment Weekly's free daily newsletter to get breaking TV news, exclusive first looks, recaps, reviews, interviews with your favorite stars, and more.\n\nVance's comments have drawn widespread ire from Americans, including Whoopi Goldberg, who harshly criticized Vance from her post on The View on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"Sir, there are people who have chosen not to have children for whatever reason. There are people who want to have children who cannot. How dare you,\" the 68-year-old said.\n\nGoldberg continued: \"You never had a baby; your wife had a baby. {"uri": "2024-07-433717881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:09:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:09:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:32:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://washingtonpost.com/style/2024/07/25/childless-cat-lady-jd-vance-jennifer-aniston-response/", "title": "'Childless cat ladies,' Jennifer Aniston, and Swifties take on JD Vance", "body": "Three years ago, well before JD Vance was selected as Donald Trump's running mate, he suggested in a TV interview that some Democrats including Vice President Harris are \"a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable.\"\n\nThose 2021 comments are resurfacing on social media now that Harris is the likely Democratic nominee, sparking a fresh wave of anger from women who say it's offensive to those struggling with fertility issues - and inaccurate that people without children \"don't really have a direct stake\" in the country's future.\n\nAt the same time, many on social media are embracing and owning the \"childless cat lady\" label as a point of pride, with many even pointing to reported billionaire Taylor Swift as a prime example of a highly successful one - seen even on her 2023 Time \"Person of the Year\" cover with her fluffy rag doll wrapped around her neck.\n\n\"There's a movement,\" declared Nikki Barnes, a previous member of the Democratic National Committee from Florida, accompanied by a \"Childless cat ladies for Harris 2024\" image quickly amassing nearly 2 million views. On TikTok, people are snapping up \"Cat ladies for Harris 2024\" stickers.\n\nThe vociferous response to the resurfaced Vance comments - which have been shared widely and amassed nearly 28 million views on an X post shared Monday - only underscores how female reproductive rights including access to abortion, birth control and in vitro fertilization will be a major drivers in the 2024 race. Gender and racial attacks like the ones she experienced as a primary candidate in the 2020 race are poised to accelerate now that she's the likely nominee.\n\nFor the record, Harris, 59, became a stepmom of two when she married Douglas Emhoff in 2014 and has been deeply involved in the lives of stepchildren Ella and Cole. And Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, whom Vance also named in his comments describing how \"the entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without children,\" became a parent of adopted twins.\n\nHarris spokesman Ammar Moussa said that \"unlike Donald Trump and JD Vance, Vice President Harris understands that every single American has a stake in this country's future.\"\n\nBiological children are not always an option, women remind Vance\n\nVance's campaign is pointing to a different speech from the July 2021 in which he targeted the \"childless left\" but added a caveat: that \"there are people, of course, for biological reasons, medical reasons that can't have children. The target of these remarks is not them.\"\n\nYet many women are reminding Vance that there are plenty of reasons they may not have children.\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States,\" actress Jennifer Aniston wrote Wednesday, slamming Vance in an Instagram story. \"Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day,\" wrote the \"Friends\" star.\n\n\"I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\" (While Trump has declared support for in vitro fertilization, Senate Republicans last month blocked consideration of a bill to protect IVF access - and the issue erupted in February when the Alabama Supreme Court ruled that frozen embryos are people and that a person could be liable for destroying them.)\n\nReproductive health issues, especially conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and endometriosis can impact women's ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy. Female fertility declines with age and lack of adequate health-care services or child support services can also be factors influencing the decision to have a child.\n\nAniston has previously been candid about the challenges of trying to get pregnant - and has previously written about how \"we don't need to be married or mothers to be complete.\"\n\n'The View\" host Whoopi Goldberg also weighed in on the show Wednesday: \"Sir, there are people who have chosen not to have children for whatever reason,\" she said. \"There are people who want to have children who cannot. How dare you. You never had a baby; your wife had a baby ... you know nothing about this.\"\n\nMeghan McCain, talk show host and daughter of the late GOP senator John McCain of Arizona, posted on X that \"I have been trying to warn every conservative man I know - these JD comments are activating women across all sides, including my most conservative Trump supporting friends.\" The remarks \"have caused real pain and are just innately unchristian. This is not who we are,\" she said.\n\nButtigieg in a CNN interview, said Vance's remarks came on the heels of their difficult journey to adoption. \"He couldn't have known that, but maybe that's why you shouldn't be talking about other people's children,\" Buttigieg said.\n\n'Childless cat ladies' are embracing the label on social media\n\nVance, in his 2021 comments, called out \"childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices they've made and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable too.\" Women online blasted the assumption that those who are without children are unhappy.\n\n\"I had absolutely no idea I was miserable,\" actor Liz Vassey, known for her role on \"CSI,\" wrote on X. \"Thank God there was a man around to tell me.\"\n\nVance's comments came as more Americans are choosing not to have children. A Pew Research Survey in 2021 found that the childless U.S. adults aged 18 to 49 who said they were unlikely to ever have children rose by 7 percentage points in the previous three years to 44 percent. About 56 percent said they did not want children, 19 percent stated a medical reason for not having kids, and financial reasons stopped another 17 percent from becoming a parent.\n\nAs some on social media put it: Childless cat ladies vote, too - and some, even, are cultural icons. \"It's bold, for someone seeking votes, to hone in on 'childless cat ladies' when the leader of Childless Cat Ladies is TAYLOR SWIFT,\" author Caitlin Moran posted. Swift, 34, has three cats and has described them as some of her biggest influences.\n\nSure enough, Swifties were entering the chat in droves. One TikToker added Swift's Time cover to the soundtrack of \"Who's Afraid of Little Old Me?\"\n\nAnother posted a video of Swift riding a giant rendering of her cat Olivia dressed as a unicorn, with the text: \"Childless cat ladies riding to polls in November to vote for Harris.\"\n\nLegal fellow and Lawfare correspondent Anna Bower pointed out on X: \"hell hath no fury like a certain childless cat lady who has yet to endorse a presidential candidate.\"", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243177279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:55:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:55:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:55:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://theblast.com/615145/jennifer-aniston-slams-j-d-vance-for-childless-woman-comments/", "title": "Jennifer Aniston Slams JD Vance For 'Childless' Woman Comments", "body": "Jennifer Aniston, who rarely talks politics with the public or media, has hit her boiling point and is speaking her mind.\n\nThe \"Friends\" actress took to her Instagram Stories after hearing J.D. Vance's recent comments about \"childless\" women, completely slamming Donald Trump's running mate.\n\nJ.D. Vance's comment has received backlash from many, including Jennifer Aniston, who has struggled with fertility.\n\nIn a recently resurfaced video from a 2021 episode of Tucker Carlson's former Fox News show, J.D. Vance, who, at the time, was a candidate for the Ohio Senate, made a striking statement.\n\nVance claimed that the United States was being governed by \"a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable with their own lives and the choices they've made, and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable, too.\"\n\nHe also said, \"It's just a basic fact -- you look at Kamala Harris, Pete Buttigieg, AOC -- the entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without children. And how does it make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it?\"\n\nAfter seeing the resurfaced clip, Jennifer Aniston took to her Instagram Stories to express her opinions.\n\n\"All I can say is... Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day,\" the actress wrote on her Instagram stories. \"I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option.\"\n\n\"Because you are trying to take that away from her, too,\" she added.\n\nThis comes two years after Aniston revealed that she struggled with her fertility and underwent IVF.\n\n\"I was trying to get pregnant. It was a challenging road for me, the baby-making road,\" Aniston told Allure, recalling the struggles she faced during her 30s and 40s. \"All the years and years and years of speculation... It was really hard. I was going through IVF, drinking Chinese teas, you name it. I was throwing everything at it.\"\n\n\"I would've given anything if someone had said to me, 'Freeze your eggs. Do yourself a favor.' You just don't think it,\" she continued. \"So here I am today. The ship has sailed.\"\n\n\"God forbid a woman is successful and doesn't have a child,\" she also said in 2022. \"And the reason my husband left me, why we broke up and ended our marriage, was because I wouldn't give him a kid. It was absolute lies.\"\n\nThe comment regarding \"childless\" women is, by far, the only comment that has gotten Vance in some trouble.\n\nAfter Donald Trump named J.D. Vance as his running mate, another clip has resurfaced, this one regarding his comments on \"violent\" marriages.\n\n\"This is one of the great tricks that I think the sexual revolution pulled on the American populace, which is the idea that like, 'Well, OK, these marriages were fundamentally, you know, they were maybe even violent, but certainly they were unhappy,\" he said, per NewsWeek. \"And so getting rid of them and making it easier for people to shift spouses like they change their underwear, that's going to make people happier in the long term.'\n\n\"And maybe it worked out for the moms and dads, though I'm skeptical. But it really didn't work out for the kids of those marriages,\" Vance added.\n\nWhen asked about the comments, Trump's running mate later said, \"I reject the premise of your bogus question. As anyone who studies these issues knows: domestic violence has skyrocketed in recent years and is much higher among non-married couples. \"\n\n\"That's the 'trick' I reference: that domestic violence would somehow go down if progressives got what they want, when in fact modern society's war on families has made our domestic violence situation much worse,\" he said. \"Any fair person would recognize I was criticizing the progressive frame on this issue, not embracing it.\"\n\n\"But I can see that you are not a fair person, so rather than answer your loaded and baseless question, let me offer the following: I'm an actual victim of domestic violence. In my life, I have seen siblings, wives, daughters, and myself abused by men,\" Vance continued. \"It's disgusting for you to argue that I was defending those men.\"", "source": {"uri": "theblast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Blast"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kelly_coffey_behrens@theblast.com", "name": "Kelly Coffey-Behrens", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._D._Vance", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "J. {"uri": "8243736819", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:00:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:00:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:58:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://turnto10.com/features/national-entertainment/jennifer-aniston-blasts-jd-vance-over-childless-cat-ladies-comment-from-2021-interview-2024-presidential-election-voting-vote-polls-politics-joe-biden-donald-trump-womens-rights-birth-pregnancy-ivf-fertilization-friends-the-morning-show", "title": "Jennifer Aniston blasts JD Vance over 'childless cat ladies' comment from 2021 interview", "body": "WASHINGTON (TND) -- Actor Jennifer Aniston is speaking out on social media about her distaste for a comment J.D. Vance made during a news interview a few years ago when he was running for a seat in the Senate.\n\nAniston shared a post on Instagram that includes video of the segment, showing Vance talking to then-FOX News host Tucker Carlson. In the video, Vance said women who haven't given birth are \"childless cat ladies\" and don't have \"a direct stake\" in the U.S.\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of the United States,\" Aniston wrote in an Instagram story Wednesday. \"All I can say is...Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\"\n\nAniston, 55, has been vocal about her fertility struggles. In 2022, she told Allure she faced several challenges while trying to conceive, including \"intense media scrutiny\" and unsuccessful in vitro fertilization, or IVF.\n\n\"I was going through IVF, drinking Chinese teas, you name it. I was throwing everything at it,\" she told the media outlet. \"I would've given anything if someone had said to me, 'Freeze your eggs. Do yourself a favor.' You just don't think it. So here I am today. The ship has sailed.\"\n\nThe video of Vance resurfaced on social media after former President Donald Trump, who is seeking a second term, announced Vance would be his running mate. President Joe Biden dropped out of the race, with Vice President Kamala Harris pursuing the Democratic party's nomination.\n\nHarris, who is married to Doug Emhoff, is the step-mother to two children.\n\n\"It doesn't make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it,\" Vance previously told Carlson. \"We're effectively run in this country via the Democrats, via our corporate oligarchs, by a bunch of childish cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made, and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable, too. And it's just a basic fact. If you look at Kamala Harris, Pete Buttigieg, [Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez] -- the entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without have children. And how does it make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it?\"\n\nAniston then shared a clip of Harris at the 2018 confirmation hearings of Supreme Court Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh. Harris asks Kavanaugh if he can \"think of any laws that give the government the power to make decisions about the male body?\"\n\nKavanaugh responds, \"I am not thinking of any right now.\"\n\nNext, Aniston posted a cartoon from The New Yorker that shows a child upset with his mother.\n\n\"So, I can't tell a lie but the Supreme Court gets to do whatever the f*** it wants?\" the child says to his mom.\n\nAccording to a new poll from The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research, few Americans fully endorse the idea that a fertilized egg should have the same rights as a pregnant woman.\n\nThe new survey comes as questions grow around reproductive health access in the continued fallout from the decision by the Supreme Court to end federal abortion protections. The poll found that a solid majority of Americans oppose a federal abortion ban as a rising number support access to abortions for any reason.\n\nPro-life advocates are increasingly pushing for broader measures that would give rights and protections to embryos and fetuses, which could have massive implications for fertility treatments and other areas of health care.\n\nAniston rose to fame for her role as Rachel Green on NBC's hit sitcom \"Friends,\" which aired from 1994 to 2004. She earned multiple awards for the role, including an Emmy, a Golden Globe, and a Screen Actors Guild award.\n\nShe has also starred in movies such as \"Office Space,\" \"Rock Star,\" and \"Marley & Me,\" just to name a few. Vance over 'cat lady' attack on Kamala Harris", "body": "The Friends star, who has struggled with infertility, took aim at comments by Trump\u2019s running mate on people who don\u2019t have children\n\nJennifer Aniston has entered the 2024 election news cycle to call out former US president Donald Trump\u2019s running mate \u2013 Hillbilly Elegy author and Ohio Senator J.D. Vance \u2013 over his remarks about people who haven\u2019t borne children.\n\nThe Emmy-winning Friends star on Wednesday shared her disbelief over a resurfaced clip of the Republican nominee for US vice-president, who in 2021 likened Democrats like Vice-President Kamala Harris to \u201cchildless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they\u2019ve made\u201d.\n\nVance said: \u201cThey want to make the rest of the country miserable too.\u201d\n\nPosting a tweet about the clip on her Instagram story, the actor wrote: \u201cI truly can\u2019t believe this is coming from a potential VP of the United States.\u201d\n\nThe Morning Show star, who opened up about her infertility struggles in 2022, then directed her comments to Vance himself while alluding to the Republican Party\u2019s support of personhood laws that would affect access to abortion, in vitro fertilisation procedures and certain types of contraception.\n\nJD Vance says women who haven\u2019t given birth like Kamala Harris are \u201cchildless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives,\u201d and have \u201cno direct stake\u201d in America. pic.twitter.com/3DJY3pQTGe\n\n\u2014 Ron Filipkowski (@RonFilipkowski) July 22, 2024\n\n\u201cAll I can say is \u2026 Mr Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day,\u201d she wrote. \u201cI hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\u201d\n\nRepresentatives for Aniston did not immediately respond on Thursday to a request for comment by the Los Angeles Times.\n\nThe senator from Ohio, 39, was a candidate for the US Congress when he made the remarks in 2021 on former Fox News host Tucker Carlson\u2019s show, but the clip has made the rounds on social media recently in the wake of Trump tapping his one-time critic as his running mate at the Republican National Convention last week.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just a basic fact \u2013 you look at Kamala Harris, [Transport Secretary] Pete Buttigieg, AOC [congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez] \u2013 the entire future of the Democrats is controlled by people without children. And how does it make any sense that we\u2019ve turned our country over to people who don\u2019t really have a direct stake in it?\u201d Vance told Carlson.\n\nAfter taking aim at Vance, Aniston, 55, appeared to endorse Harris, who stepped into the race Sunday after US President Joe Biden heeded widespread calls to drop out of the election. She reposted a 2018 video from fellow actor Allison Janney showing the former prosecutor and senator grilling Justice Brett Kavanaugh, then a US Supreme Court nominee, on abortion rights.\n\nIn a 2022 interview, Aniston provided rare insight into her attempts at parenthood and how the media scrutinised her about not having children during her high-profile marriages to Brad Pitt and Justin Theroux.\n\n\u201cI was trying to get pregnant. It was a challenging road for me, the baby-making road,\u201d she told Allure. \u201cAll the years and years and years of speculation \u2026 It was really hard. I was going through IVF, drinking Chinese teas, you name it. I was throwing everything at it. I would\u2019ve given anything if someone had said to me, \u2018Freeze your eggs. Do yourself a favour.\u2019 You just don\u2019t think it. So here I am today. The ship has sailed.\u201d\n\nAniston said that the media painfully labelled her as \u201cselfish\u201d and someone who \u201cjust cared about her career\u201d.\n\n\u201cGod forbid a woman is successful and doesn\u2019t have a child,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd the reason my husband left me, why we broke up and ended our marriage, was because I wouldn\u2019t give him a kid. It was absolute lies.\u201d\n\nMeanwhile, Harris\u2019 stepdaughter Ella Emhoff and Ella\u2019s mother, Kerstin Emhoff, came to Harris\u2019 defence.\n\nElla Emhoff posted a statement her mother had given to CNN on her Instagram story on Thursday. In it, Kerstin Emhoff called the \u201cchildless\u201d claims against Harris \u201cbaseless\u201d and praised Harris as a \u201cco-parent\u201d to her two children with second gentleman Doug Emhoff.\n\n\u201cShe is loving, nurturing, fiercely protective, and always present,\u201d the statement said.\n\nElla Emhoff added: \u201cHow can you be \u2018childless\u2019 when you have cutie pie kids like cole and I. @kemhoff say it louder for the people in the back \u2026 I love my three parents.\u201d", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "South China Morning Post"}, He even claimed that these women \"want to make the rest of the country miserable too\".\n\nJennifer's reaction prompted many online to look back on her documented struggles with becoming a mother. {"uri": "8243655993", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:27:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:27:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:26:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1341647", "title": "Title of the Page", "body": "(WASHINGTON) -- A Fox News interview from 2021, in which Sen. JD Vance smeared Vice President Kamala Harris as a \"childless cat lady,\" has resurfaced since he became the Republican vice presidential nominee, sparking widespread anger.\n\nIn the clip, Vance questioned Democrats -- including Harris, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg and U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez -- for not having biological children.\n\n\"We are effectively run in this country via the Democrats, via our corporate oligarchs, by a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made and so they want to make the rest of the country miserable too,\" Vance said.\n\n\"How does it make any sense that we've turned our country over to people who don't really have a direct stake in it?\" he asked.\n\nThe 2021 interview began circulating widely after Hillary Clinton shared the clip on X. \"What a normal, relatable guy who certainly doesn't hate women having freedoms,\" she wrote.\n\nVance did not immediately respond to a request for comment from ABC News.\n\nThough Harris does not have biological children, she does have two stepchildren -- Cole and Ella Emhoff -- who have lovingly referred to her as \"Momala.\"\n\nKerstin Emhoff -- second gentleman Doug Emhoff's ex-wife, and mother to Cole and Ella Emhoff -- has been a vocal supporter of Harris, and defended her against attacks about her parental status.\n\n\"These are baseless attacks. For over 10 years, since Cole and Ella were teenagers, Kamala has been a co-parent with Doug and I,\" she said. \"She is loving, nurturing, fiercely protective, and always present. I love our blended family and am grateful to have her in it.\"\n\nElla Emhoff shared her mother's statement on Instagram, writing, \"I love my three parents.\"\n\n\"How can you be 'childless' when you have cutie pie kids like Cole and I?\" she added.\n\nButtigieg also hit back against Vance's comments, saying in a CNN interview that Vance should not speak about other people's children.\n\n\"The really sad thing is he said that after Chasten and I had been through a fairly heartbreaking setback in our adoption journey,\" Buttigieg said. \"He couldn't have known that, but maybe that's why you shouldn't be talking about other people's children, and it's not about his kids or my kids or the vice president's family. It's about your family, people's families whose well-being will depend on whether we go into a future led by somebody like Kamala Harris, who is focused on expanding the prosperity, the freedom, the well-being of our families.\n\nActress Jennifer Aniston, who has spoken about her struggles with fertility, made a post on Instagram slamming Vance, who has voted against establishing federal protections for in vitro fertilization.\n\n\"I truly can't believe this is coming from a potential VP of The United States,\" Aniston wrote. \"All I can say is ... Mr Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her too.\"\n\nVance's comments have even struck a nerve with some prominent conservative women.\n\n\"One of my best friends did rounds and rounds of unsuccessful IVF wanting to have a child. It is still painful to talk about,\" Meghan McCain said in an X post. \"This 'childless women' comment by JD Vance has made so many waves with so many different friends of mine for its insensitivity and cruelty to women.\"\n\nBeverly Hallberg, a fellow with the conservative nonprofit Independent Women's Forum, replied to McCain's post.\n\n\"I'm childless on earth, but I have a baby in heaven due to an ectopic pregnancy,\" Hallberg said. \"Not all women who don't have children are childless by choice. It adds insult to injury, to put it mildly, when these comments are said.\"\n\nCorie Whalen, media relations director at a Republican think tank and former congressional staffer, said on X she was disgusted by Vance's comments.\n\n\"I'm a right-leaning woman who agrees with almost nothing the Biden-Harris administration has done, but the primal hatred and disgust Vance stokes in me transcends politics,\" she wrote. \"I suspect I am not the only woman of my vintage, so to speak, who feels this way.\"\n\nThe head of a major infertility nonprofit also spoke out against Vance, calling his comments \"painful and tone-deaf.\"\n\n\"People are childfree for many reasons -- from grieving the pain of miscarriage to experiencing failed adoptions or rounds of fertility treatments to making their own choice not to have children,\" said Barbara Collura, president and CEO of RESOLVE: The National Infertility Association.\n\n\"For some, living without children doesn't feel like a choice that they made, but a choice that they live with, despite trying to grow their families,\" Collura added. \"Under no circumstances, should living childfree be weaponized in a way that degrades people or their value to society.\"\n\nIn an interview with ABC News at the American Teachers Federation Conference in Houston, Briget Rein -- a former Brooklyn teacher, who wore a pink shirt that said \"Cats Against Trump\" -- proudly identified herself as a \"cat lady\" and said she thought Vance's remarks were \"stupid.\"\n\n\"Vance also is unprepared to be a vice president, he's not prepared. Because he's busy looking at the surface. He's not looking at the full picture,\" she said.\"You know, this cat lady went to college. This cat lady went to work ... but he's busy talking about cat ladies, and talking about women in a very derogatory fashion.\"", "source": {"uri": "ktbb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBB"}, Mr. Vance, I pray that your daughter is fortunate enough to bear children of her own one day. I hope she will not need to turn to IVF as a second option. Because you are trying to take that away from her, too.\"\n\nWhat did JD Vance say about 'childless cat ladies?'\n\nThe conversation between Vance and Carlson aired on Fox News in July 2021, when Vance was running for Ohio's U.S. Senate seat.\n\n\"We are effectively run in this country ... by a bunch of childless cat ladies who are miserable at their own lives and the choices that they've made, and so they wanna make the rest of the country miserable, too,\" Vance told Carlson. \"It's just a basic fact.
